content: The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to offer interest-bearing transaction accounts to businesses, permitting up to 24 transfers per month. It also authorizes the payment of earnings on reserves held at Federal Reserve Banks, with regulations on payment frequency and distribution to depository institutions. It authorizes the distribution of earnings on reserves held at Federal Reserve Banks to depository institutions, including trust companies. The responsibilities of various entities regarding the crediting and distribution of earnings are outlined in the Act. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to include trust companies and foreign bank branches as depository institutions. Member banks are authorized for pass-through reserves. Technical and conforming amendments are made to Section 19 of the Act. SEC. 4 amends the Federal Reserve Act to increase flexibility in setting reserve requirements. The ratio can now be not greater than 3 percent (including zero) and not less than zero. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to require additional transfers from surplus funds of Federal Reserve banks to cover interest payments for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. The Federal Reserve Board will determine the amount each bank must pay in each fiscal year, and any excess surplus funds will be transferred to the Secretary of the Treasury. During fiscal years 2003 through 2007, any surplus funds in excess of 3 percent of the paid-in capital and surplus of Federal Reserve banks will be transferred to the Secretary of the Treasury for deposit in the general fund.
